DIV1.P: As it is performed at the THEATRE ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
Taken from MOLIERE and CIBBER, By the AUTHOR Of the ALTERATIONS of the PLAIN-DEALER.
LONDON: Printed for W. GRIFFIN, at GARRICK'S Head, in Catharine-street, Strand.

DIV1.HEAD: PREFACE.
DIV1.P: HAD any objections been made to this play, worth taking notice of, I should be un∣der no obligations to answer them, being ac∣countable for none of it's faults, as I lay claim to none of it's beauties. Cibber's Non-Juror (bor∣rowed from the Tartuffe of Moliere) has ever been reckoned an excellent comedy; but be∣ing written to expose a party, it was no longer interesting, because the folly and roguery it de∣sign'd to ridicule, no longer existed: It was thought, that it might be render'd agreeable to the present times, by once more having recourse to Moliere; and, with that view, I have endea∣vour'd to substitute his celebrated character of Tartuffe, in the room of Doctor Wolf.

Mr. Garrick determin'd to do this about two years ago; but, because the consequence of suc∣cess wou'd be a benefit easily gotten, he kindly put it into my hands, with some hints for the
alteration. He did not think it was necessary to have any thing new, besides a short character for that entertaining comedian, Mr. Weston: Maw-worm therefore in this play is written by me, and scarce any thing more. For the rest, the character of Doctor Cantwell, as it here stands, is almost a verbal translation from Moliere, as old Lady Lambert is a counterpart of Madam Pernelle.

All the world knows, that the Tartuffe is reckon'd among the Chef des Oeuvres of the French Theatre; I may therefore presume with∣out any vanity, in spite of the ignorance and malevolence of little judges, that the man who takes two such plays as I have had to work upon, cou'd not, under the direction of Mr. Garrick, produce a very bad one; especi∣ally if he presum'd to foist in little or nothing of his own: And the remarkably kind reception the public have given to this Comedy, makes me believe they are well content with my humble endeavour to entertain them.

Gratitude, however, obliges me to take notice of the great assistance I have receiv'd from Mrs. Abington and Mr. King. The former, in the character of Charlotte, (Cibber's admirable Maria) is so excellent, that I cannot conceive it possible for any actress ever to have gone beyond
her. There is a natural ease and vivacity in her manner, and, in this part particularly, a fashionable deportment (if I may use the ex∣pression) which gives a brilliancy to every thing she says, and has in a very uncommon manner, engaged the attention and applause of the town. The latter, in the part of the Hypocrite, has shewn that he is capable of assuming cha∣racters the most difficult, and at the same time the most opposite; and, by each new effort, to add to the esteem which the public appears to have for him.

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS.
DIV1.P: Scene, Sir JOHN LAMBERT'S House in LONDON.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A hall in Sir JOHN LAMBERT's house. Sir JOHN LAMBERT enters, followed by Colonel LAMBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel LAMBERT.
SP.P: PRAY, consider, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: So I do, Sir, that I am her Father, and will dispose of her as I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I do not dispute your authority, Sir; but as I am your son too, I think it my duty to be concern'd for your honour. Have not you countenanc'd his addres∣ses to my sister? has not she received them?—Mr. Darnley's birth and fortune are well known to you, and, I dare swear, he may defy the world to lay a blemish on his character.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why then, Sir, since I am to be catechiz'd, I must tell you, I do not like his character: he is a world∣server, a libertine, and has no more religion than you have.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Sir, we neither of us think it proper to make a boast of our religion; but, if you will please to en∣quire, you will find that we go to church as orderly as the rest of our neighbours.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Oh! you go to church! you go to church!—Wonderful! wonderful! to bow, and grin, and cough, and sleep: a fine act of devotion indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, but dear Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Colonel, you are an atheist.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir! I am none: it is a character I abhor; and, next to that, I abhor the character of an enthusiast.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Oh, you do so; an enthusiast!—this is the fashion∣able phrase, the bye-word, the nick-name, that our pleasure-loving generation give to those few who have a sense of true sanctity.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Say, canting Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: I tell you what, Son, as I have told you more than once, you will draw some heavy judgment on your head one day or other.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: So says the charitable Doctor Cantwell: you have taken him into your house, and, in return, he gives over half your family to the devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Do not abuse the Doctor, Colonel; it is not the way to my favour. I know you cannot bear him, be∣cause he is not one of your mincing preachers.—He holds up the candle to your enormities, shews you to yourselves in your genuine colours.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P:
I always respect piety and virtue, Sir; but there are pretenders to religion, as well as to courage: and as we never find the truly brave to be such as make much noise about their valour; so, I apprehend, the truly good seldom or ever deal much in grimace.—
To be candid, Sir, I make a distinction between hy∣pocrisy and devotion, and can never pay the same regard to the mask, that I would to the face.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Very well, Sir; this is very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Besides, Sir, I should be glad to know, by what authority the Doctor pretends to exercise the clerical function.—It does not appear clearly to me, that he ever was in orders.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: That is no business of yours, Sir.—But I am better informed.—However, he has the call of zeal.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Zeal!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why, Colonel, you are in a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I own, I cannot see with temper, Sir, so many re∣ligious mountebanks impose on the unwary multi∣tude; wretches, who make a trade of religion, and shew an uncommon concern for the next world, only to raise their fortunes with greater security in this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Colonel, let me hear no more: I see you are too hardned to be converted now; but since you think it your duty, as a son, to be concerned for my errors; I think it as much mine, as a father, to be concerned for yours.—If you think fit to mend them so; if not, take the consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, Sir, may I ask you without offence, if the reasons you have given me are your only reasons, for discountenancing Mr. Darnley's addresses to my sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Are they not flagrant? would you have me marry my daughter to a Pagan?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: He intends this morning paying his respects to you, in hopes to obtain your final consent, and de∣sir'd me to be present, as a mediator of articles be∣tween you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: I am glad to hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: That's kind, indeed, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: May be not, Sir; for I will not be at home when he comes; and because I will not tell a lie for the matter, I will go out this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Nay, dear Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: And, do you hear, because I will not deceive him, either, tell him I would not have him lose his time in fooling after your sister—In short, I have another man in my head for her.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: Colonel LAMBERT, and then CHARLOTTE.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Another man! it would be worth one's while to know him; pray heav'n this canting Hypocrite has not got some beggarly rascal in his eye for her.—I must rid the house of him at any rate, or all the settlement I can hope from my father, is a castle in the air,—my sister may be ruin'd too—Here she comes: if there be another man in the case, she, no doubt, can let me into the secret.—Sister, good morrow, I want to speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Prythee then, dear brother, don't put on that wise politic face, as if your regiment was going to be dis∣banded, or sent to the West Indies, and you obliged to follow it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Come, come, a truce with your raillery; what I have to ask of you is serious, and I beg you would be o in your answer.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well then, provided it is not upon the subject of love, I will be so—but make haste too—for I have not had my tea yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why it is, and it is not, upon that subject.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O, I love a riddle dearly—Come—lets hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: —Nay, psha! if you will be serious, say so.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O lard, Sir; I beg your pardon—there—there's my whole form and features, totally disengag'd, and lifeless at your service; now, put them in what pos∣ture of attention you think sit.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Was there ever such a giddy devil!—prythee stand up, I have been talking with my father, and he de∣clares positively, you shall not receive any further addresses from Mr. Darnley.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Are you serious?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: He said so this minute, and with some warmth.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I am glad on't with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: How! glad!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: To a degree. Do you think a man has any more charms for me for my father's liking him? No, Sir; if Mr. Darnley can make his way to me now, he is obliged to me only. Besides, now it may have the face of an amour indeed; now one has something to struggle for; there's difficulty, there's danger, there's the dear spirit of contradiction in it too: O! I like it mightily.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P:
I am glad this does not make you think the worse of Darnley—but a father's consent might have clap't
a pair of horses more to your coach perhaps, and the want of it may pinch your fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Burn fortune; am not I a fine woman? and have not I ten thousand pounds in my own hands?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Yes, sister; but, with all your charms, you have had them in your hands almost these four years.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Psha! and have not I had the full swing of my own airs and humours these four years? but if I humour my father, I warrant, he'll make it three or four thousand more, with some unlick'd lout: a com∣fortable equivalent, truly—No, no; let him light his pipe with his consent, if he please. Wilful against wise for a wager.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well said; nothing goes to your heart, I find.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: No, no; if I must have an ill match, I'll have the pleasure of playing my own game at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: But pray, sister, has my father ever propos'd any other man to you?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Another man! let me know why you ask, and I'll tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why, the last words he said to me were, that he had another man in his head for you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: And who is it? who is it? tell me, dear brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why you don't so much as seem surpris'd.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: No; but I'm impatient, and that's as well.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why, how now, sister?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Why, sure, brother, you know very little of female happiness, if you suppose the surprise of a new lover ought to shock a woman of my temper—don't you know that I am a coquette?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: If you are, you are the first that ever was sincere enough to own her being so.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: To a lover, I grant you; but I make no more of you than a sister: I can say any thing to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I should have been better pleas'd, if you had not own'd it to me—its a hateful character!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Ay, its no matter for that; it's violently pleasant▪ and there's no law against it, that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Darnley's like to have a hopeful time with you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well; but don't you really know who it is my father intends me?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Not I, really; but I imagin'd you might, and there∣fore thought to advise with you about it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Nay, he has not open'd his lips to me yet—are you sure he's gone out?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: You are very impatient to know, methinks; what have you to do to concern yourself about any man but Darnley?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O lud! O lud! Prythee, brother, don't be so wise; if you had an empty house to let, would you be dis∣pleased to hear there were two people about it? Be∣sides, to be a little serious: Darnley has a tincture of jealousy in his temper, which nothing but a substan∣tial rival can cure.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: O, your servant, Madam! now, you talk reason. I am glad you are concern'd enough for Darnley's faults, to think them worth your mending—ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Concern'd! why, did I say that—look you, I'll deny it all to him—well, if I ever am serious with you again—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Here he comes; be as merry with him as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Psha!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: Colonel LAMBERT, CHARLOTTE, DARNLEY; CHARLOTTE takes a book and reads.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: My dear colonel, your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I am glad you did not come sooner; for in the humour my father left me, 'twould not have been a pro∣per time to have press'd your affair—I touch'd upon't—but—I'll tell you more presently; in the mean time lose no ground with my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I shall always think myself oblig'd to your friend∣ship, let my success be what it will—Madam—your most obedient—what have you got there, pray?

Q.L: "Her lively looks a sprightly mind disclose;
"Quick as her eyes, and as unfix'd as those—

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, what is it?

Q.L: "Favours to none, to all she smiles extends—

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Nay I will see—

Q.L: "Oft she rejects, but never once offends.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Have a care: she has dip't into her own character, and she'll never forgive you, if you don't let her go through with it.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, Madam.

Q.L: "Bright as the sun her eyes the gazers strike,
"And like the sun they shine on all alike—um—um—

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: That is something like, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: You wou'd say so, if you knew all.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: All what! pray what do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Have a little patience: I'll tell you immediately.

LG.L: "If to her share some female errors fall,
"Look on her face—and you'll forget them all.
Is not that natural, Mr. Darnley?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: For a woman to expect, it is indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: And can you blame her, when 'tis at the same time a proof of the poor man's passion, and her power?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: So that, you think, the greatest compliment a lover can make his mistress, is to give up his reason to her.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Certainly; for what have your sex to boast of but your understanding, and till that's entirely surrender'd to her discretion, while the least sentiment holds out against her, a woman must be downright vain, to think her conquest compleated.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: There we differ, Madam; for, in my opinion, no∣thing, but the most excessive vanity could value or desire such a conquest.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O d'ye hear him brother? the creature reasons with me; nay, has the effrontery to think me in the wrong too! O lud! he'd make an horrid tyrant—positively I won't have him.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Well; my comfort is, no other man will easily know whether you'll have him or not.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Am I not an horrid, vain, silly creature, Mr. Darn∣ley?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: A little bordering upon the baby, I must own.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Laud! how can you love one so then? but I don't think you love me tho'—do you?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Yes, faith, I do; and so shamefully, that I'm in hopes you doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Poor man! he'd fain bring me to reason.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I would, indeed.—Nay, were it but possible to make you serious only when you should be so, I should think you the most amiable—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O lud, he's civil—

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Come, come, you have good sense; use me but with that, and make me what you please.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Laud! I don't desire to make any thing of you, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Don't look so cold upon me; by heav'n I can't bear it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, now you are tolerable.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Come then, be generous, and swear, at least, you'll never marry another.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Ah, Laud! now you have spoil'd all again: be∣sides, how can I be sure of that, before I have seen this other man my brother spoke to me of?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: What riddle's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I told you, you did not know all: to be serious; my father went out but now, on purpose to avoid you.—In short, he absolutely retracts his promises; says, he would not have you fool away your time after my sister; and, in plain terms, told me, he had another man in his head for her.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Another man! who? what is he? did not he name him?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: No; nor has he yet spoke of him to my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: This is unaccountable!—what can have given him this sudden turn?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Some whim our conscientious Doctor has put in his head, I'll lay my life.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: He! he can't be such a villain; he professes a friendship for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: So much the worse.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: But on what pretence, what grounds, what reason, what interest can he have to oppose me?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Are you really now as unconcerned as you seem to be?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You are a strange dunce, brother—you know no more of love, than I do of a regiment—you shall see now how I'll comfort him—poor Darnley, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I don't wonder at your good humour, Madam, when you have so substantial an opportunity to make me uneasy for life.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O lud! how sententious he is! well, his reproaches have that greatness of soul—the confusion they give one is insupportable—Betty, is the tea ready?

SP.SPEAKER: BETTY.
SP.P: Yes, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Mr. Darnley, your servant.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: Colonel LAMBERT, DARNLEY.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: So; you have made a fine spot of work, on't indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Dear Tom, pardon me, if I speak a little freely; I own, the levity of her behaviour, at this time, gives me harder thoughts than I once believed it possible to have of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Indeed, my friend, you mistake her.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Nay, nay; had she any real concern for me, the apprehension of a man's addresses, whom yet she never saw, must have alarm'd her to some degree of serious∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Not a all; for let this man be who he will, I take her levity as a proof of her resolution to have nothing to say to him.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: And pray, Sir, may I not as well suspect, that this artful delay of her good nature to me now, is meant as a provisional defence against my reproaches, in case, when she has seen this man, she should think it conve∣nient to prefer him.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: No, no; she's giddy, but not capable of so study'd a falsehood.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: But still, what could she mean by going away so abruptly?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: You grew too grave for her.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Why, who could bear such trifling?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: You should have laugh'd at her.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I can't love at that easy rate.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: No—if you cou'd, the uneasiness would lie on her side.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Do you then really think she has any thing in her heart for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ay, marry, Sir—ah! if you could but get her to own that seriously now—lord! how you cou'd love her!

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: And so I could, by heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, well; I'll undertake for her; if my father don't stand in the way, we are well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: What says my lady? you don't think she's against us?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I dare swear she is not. She's of so soft, so sweet a disposition—

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Prythee, how came so fine a woman to marry your father, with such a vast inequality of years?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Want of fortune, Frank: she was poor and beauti∣ful—he rich and amorous—she made him happy, and he her—

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: A lady—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: And a jointure—now she's the only one in the family, that has power with our precise doctor; and, I dare engage, she'll use it with him to persuade my father from any thing that is against your interest. By the way, you must know I have some shrewd suspicion, that this sanctified rogue is in love with her.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: In love!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: You shall judge by the symptoms—but hush! here he comes with my grandmother—step this way, and I'll tell you.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: Doctor CANTWELL and Old Lady LAMBERT, followed by SEYWARD.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Charles, step up into my study; bring down a dozen more of those manuels of devotion, with the last hymns I composed; and, when he calls, give them to Mr. Maw-worm; and, do you hear, if any one enquires for me, say I am gone to Newgate, and the Marshalsea, to distribute alms.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P:
Well; but, worthy Doctor, why will you go to the prisons yourself—cannot you send the money—ugly
distempers are often catched there—have a care of your health; let us keep one good man, at least amongst us.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Alas, Madam! I am not a good man; I am a guilty wicked sinner, full of iniquity; the greatest villain that ever breathed; every instant of my life is cloud∣ed with stains; it is one continued series of crimes and defilements; you do not know what I am capable of; you indeed take me for a good man; but the truth is, I am a worthless creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Have you then stumbled? alas! if it be so, who shall walk upright? What horrid crime have you been hurried into, that calls for this severe self-recrimina∣tion?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: None, Madam, that, perhaps, humanity may call very enormous; yet am I sure, that my thoughts never stray a moment from celestial contemplations; do they not sometimes, before I am aware, turn to things of this earth? am I not often hasty, and surpris'd into wrath? nay, the instance is recent; for, last night, being snarled at, and bit by Minxy, your daughter-in-law's lap-dog, I am conscious I struck the little beast with a degree of passion, for which I have never been able to forgive myself since.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Oh! worthy, humble soul! this is a slight offence, which your suffering and mortifications may well atone for.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: No, Madam, no; I want to suffer; I ought to be mor∣tified; and I am obliged now to tell you, that, for my soul's sake, I must quit your good son's family; I am pamper'd too much here, live too much at my ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Good Doctor!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Alas, Madam! it is not you that should shed tears; it is I ought to weep; you are a pure woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I pure! who, I? no, no; sinful, sinful—but do not talk of quitting our family; what will become of us—for friendship—for charity—

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Enough; say no more, Madam; I submit; while I can do good, it is my duty.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV2.STAGE: Colonel LAMBERT, DARNLEY, Old Lady LAMBERT, Doctor CANTWELL.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Your ladyship's most humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Grandson, how do you?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Good day to you, Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Mr. Darnley, I am your most humble servant; I hope you and the good Colonel will stay, and join in the private duties of the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: No, Doctor, no; it is too early; the sun has not risen upon them; but, I doubt not, the day will come.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I warrant they would go to a play now.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Would they—I'm afraid they would.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Why, I hope it is no sin, Madam; if I am not mistaken, I have seen your ladyship at a play.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Me, Sir! see me at a play! you may have seen the prince of darkness, or some of his imps, in my like∣ness, perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Well but, Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Mr. Darnley, do you think I would commit a murder?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: No, Sir, no; these are not the plants usually to be met with in that rank soil; the seeds of wickedness indeed sprout up every where too fast; but a play∣house is the devil's hot-bed—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: And yet, Doctor, I have known some of the leaders of your tribe, as scrupulous as they are, who have been willing to gather fruit there for the use of the brethren—as in case of a benefit—

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: The charity covereth the sin; and it may be lawful to turn the wages of abomination to the comfort of the righteous.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Reprobate! Reprobate!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: What is that you mutter, sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Oh heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Let him go, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: A canting hypocrite!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Very well, Sir; your father shall know my treat∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Let me run out of the house; I shall have it fall upon my head, if I stay among such wicked wretches. O grandson! grandson! [Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV2.STAGE: Colonel LAMBERT, DARNLEY.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Was there ever so insolent a rascal?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: The dog will one day provoke me to beat his brains out.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: But what the devil is he? whence comes he? what is his original? how has he so ingratiated himself with your father, as to get footing in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: O, Sir, he is here in quality of chaplain; he was first introduc'd by the good old lady that's just gone out; you know, she has been a long time a frequenter of our modern conventicles, where, it seems she got acquainted with this sanctified pastor. His disciples believe him a saint, and my poor father, who has been for sometime tainted with their pernicious principles, has been led into the same snare.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Hah! here's your sister again.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: Colonel LAMBERT, DARNLEY, CHARLOTTE, Doctor CANTWELL.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You'll find, Sir, I will not be us'd thus; nor shall your credit with my father protect your insolence to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: What's the matter!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Nothing; pray be quiet.—I don't want you—stand out of the way—how durst you bolt with such autho∣rity into my chamber without giving me notice?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Hold—if my father won't resent this, 'tis then time enough for me to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Compose yourself, Madam; I come by your father's desire, who being informed that you were entertaining Mr. Darnley, grew impatient, and gave his positive commands that you attend him instantly, or he him∣self, he says, will fetch you.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Ay, now the storm is rising.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: So, for what I have done, Madam, I had his au∣thority, and shall leave him to answer you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: 'Tis false. He gave you no authority to insult me; or, if he had, did you suppose I would bear it from you? What is it you presume upon, your function? does that exempt you from the manners of a gentle∣man?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Shall I have an answer to your father, lady?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I'll send him none by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I shall inform him so.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV2.STAGE: Colonel LAMBERT, DARNLEY, CHARLOTTE.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: A saucy puppy!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Pray, sister, what has the fellow done to you?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I beg you would tell us, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P:
Nay, no great matter—but I was sitting carelessly in my dressing-room—a—a fastening my garter, with
my face just towards the door; and this impudent cur, without the least notice, comes bounce in upon me—and my devilish hoop happening to hitch in the chair, I was an hour before I could get down my petticoats.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: The rogue must be corrected.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Yet, egad! I can't help laughing at the accident; what a ridiculous figure must she make! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Hah! you're as impudent as he, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Now, dear Tom, speak to her before she goes.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: What does he say, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why, he wants to have me speak to you; and I would have him do it himself.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Ay, come do, Darnley; I am in a good humour now.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Oh Charlotte! my heart is bursting—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, well; out with it.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Your father, now I see, is bent on parting us—nay, what's worse perhaps, will give you to another—I cannot speak—imagine what I want from you—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well—O lud! one looks so silly tho', when one is serious—O gad—in short, I cannot get it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I warrant you; try again.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O lud—well—if one must be teiz'd then—why, he must hope, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Is't possible—thus—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Buz—not a syllable; she has done very well. I bar all Heroic's; if you press it too far, I'll hold six to four she's off again in a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I'm silenced.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Now am I on tiptoe to know, what odd fellow my father has found out for me.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I'd give something to know him.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: He's in a terrible fuss at your being here, I find.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: 'Sdeath! here he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Now we are all in a fine pickle.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE X.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir JOHN LAMBERT enters hastily; and look∣ing sternly at DARNLEY, takes CHAR∣LOTTE under his arm, and carries her off; the Colonel and DARNLEY remain.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: So—well said Doctor; 'tis he, I am sure, has blown this fire; what horrid hands is our poor family fallen into! and how the rogue seems to triumph in his power! how little is my father like himself? By nature, open, just, and generous; but, this vile Hypocrite drives his weak passions like the wind; and, I foresee at last, something fatal will be the consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Not, if by speedily detecting him, you take care to prevent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why, I have a thought that might expose him to my father, and, in some unguarded hour, we may, yet, perhaps, surprize this lurking thief without his holy vizor.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: Changes to an Anti-Chamber in Sir JOHN LAMBERT'S House.—SEYWARD, with a Writing in his Hand.
DIV2.P: 'TIS so!—I have long suspected where his zeal would end, in the making of his private for∣tune.—But then, to found it on the ruin of his Patron's children!—I shudder at the villany! What desperation may a son be driven to, so barbarously dis∣inherited!—Besides, his daughter, fair Charlotte, too is wrong'd; wrong'd in the tenderest point. For so extravagant is this settlement, that it leaves her not a shilling, unless she marries with the Doctor's con∣sent, which is intended by what I have heard, as an expedient to oblige her to marry the Doctor himself. Now, 'twere but an honest part to let Charlotte know the snare that's laid for her: This deed's not sign'd, and may be yet prevented.—It shall be so.—Yes, charm∣ing creature!—I adore you!—And tho' I am sensible that my passion is without hope, I may indulge it thus far, at least; I may have the merit of serving you, and perhaps the pleasure to know you think yourself oblig'd by me.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir JOHN, Lady LAMBERT, CHARLOTTE, and SEYWARD, who goes in and out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: O! Seyward, your uncle wants you to transcribe some hymns.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Sir, I'll wait on him. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: A pretty well-bred fellow that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ay, ay; but he has better qualities than his good▪ breeding.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: He's always clean too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: I wonder, daughter, when you will take notice of a man's real merit.—Humph, well-bread and clean, forsooth.—Wou'd not one think now she was describ∣a coxcomb?—When do you hear my wife talk at this rate, and yet she is as young as your fantastical lady∣ship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Charlotte is of a chearful temper, my dear; but I know you don't think she wants discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: I shall try that presently; and you, my dear, shall judge between us. In short, daughter, your course of life is but one continual round of playing the fool, to no purpose; and therefore I am resolv'd to make you think seriously, and marry.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: That I shall do before I marry, Sir, you may de∣pend upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Um—That I am not so sure of—but you may de∣pend upon my having thought seriously, and that's as well; for the person I intend you, is of all the world the only man can make you truly happy.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: And of all the world, Sir, that's the only man I'll positively marry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: You have rare courage, Charlotte; if I had such a game to play, I should be frighted out of my wits.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord! Madam, he'll make nothing on't, depend up∣on it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Mind what I say to you.—This wonderful man I say,—first, in his public character, is religious, zea∣lous, and charitable.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Very well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: In his private character, sober.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I should hate a sot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Chaste.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: A hem! [Stifling a laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: What is it you sneer at, Madam?—You want one of your fine gentlemen rakes, I suppose, that are snap∣ping at every woman they meet with.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: No, no, Sir; I am very well satisfied.—I—I should not care for such a sort of a man, no more than I shou'd for one that every woman was ready to snap at.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: No, you'll be secure from jealousy; he has experi∣rience, ripeness of years; he's almost forty-nine. Your sex's vanities will have no charms for him.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: But all this while, Sir, I don't find that he has charms for our sex's vanity. How does he look? Is he tall, well made? Does he dress, sing, talk, laugh, and dance well? Has he good hair, good teeth, fine eyes?—Doth he keep a chaise, coach, and vis∣a-vis? Does he wear gold stuffs, velvet, and sub∣scribe to Almack's?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Was there ever so profligate a creature! What will this age come to?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Nay, Charlotte, here I must be against you▪—Now you are blind indeed. A woman's happiness has little to do with the pleasure her husband takes in his own person.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: It is not how he looks, but how he loves, is the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Good again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: And a wife is much more secure that has charms for her husband, than when the husband has only charms for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Admirable! go on my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Do you think a woman of five and twenty may not be much happier with an honest man of fifty, than the finest woman of fifty with a young fellow of five and twenty?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Mark that!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Ay, but when two five and twenties come together,—dear papa you must allow they have a chance to be fifty times as pleasant and frolicksome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Frolicksome! Why you sensual ideot, what have frolicks to do with solid happiness? I am a sham'd of you.—Go, you talk worse than a girl at a boarding∣school.—Frolicksome! as if marriage was only a licence for two people to play the fool according to law. Me∣thinks, Madam, you have a better example of happiness before your face.—Here's one has ten times your un∣derstanding, and she, you find, has made a different choice.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P:
Lord, Sir, how you talk! you don't consider peo∣ple's tempers. I don't say my Lady is not in the right; but then, you know, papa, she's a prude, and I am a coquette; she becomes her character very well, I don't deny it; and I hope you see every thing I do, is as con∣sistent with mine; and be assur'd, you will no more be able to bring me to endure a man of forty-nine, than
you can persuade my Lady to dance in church to the organ.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why, you wicked wretch! Could any thing per∣suade you to that?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord, S r; I won't answer for what I might do if th whim was in my head; besides, you know I al∣ways lov'd a little flirtation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: O horrible! flirtation! My poor sister has ruin'd her; leaving a fortune in her own hands, has turn'd her brain. In short, Charlotte, your sentiments of life are shameful, and I am resolv'd upon your instant re∣formation; therefore, as an earnest of your obedience, I shall first insist that you never see young Darnley more; for, in one word, the good and pious Doctor Cantwell's the man that I have decreed your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Ho! ho! ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: 'Tis very well; this laugh you think becomes you, but I shall spoil your mirth—no more—give me a se∣rious answer.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I ask your pardon, Sir; I should not have smil'd indeed, cou'd I have suppos'd it possible that you were serious.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: You'll find me so.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I'm sorry for it; but I have an objection to the Doctor, Sir, that most fathers think a substantial one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Name it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Why, Sir, we know nothing of his fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: That's more than you know, Madam; I am able to give him a better estate than I'm afraid you'll deserve.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: How! Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: I have told you what's my will, and shall leave you to think on▪t.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter SEYWARD.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Sir, if you are at leasure, the Doctor desires to speak with you, upon business of importance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: In his own chamber, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: I will come to him immediately.—Daughter, I am call'd away, and therefore have only time to tell you, as my last resolution, Doctor Cantwell is your hus∣band, or I'm no more your father.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: Lady LAMBERT, CHARLOTTE, and afterwards Col. LAMBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O Madam! I am at my wit's nd; not for the little fortune I may lose in disobeying my father, but it star∣tles me to find what a dangerous influence this fellow has o'er all his actions.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Here's your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Madam, your most obedient.—Well, sister, is the ecret out? Who is this pretty fellow my father has pick'd up for you?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Even our agreeable Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: You are not serious?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: He's the very man, I can assure you▪ Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Confusion! What would the cormorant devour th whole family? Your Ladyship knows, he is secretly in love with you too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Fy, fy, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I ask your pardon, Madam, if I speak too freely: but I am sure, by what I have seen, your Ladyship must suspect something of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I am sorry any body else has seen it, but I must own, his behaviour to me of late, both in private and before company, has been something warmer than I thought became him.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: How are these opposites to be reconcil'd? Can the rascal have the assurance to think both points are to be carried?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Truly one would not suspect the gentleman to be so termagant.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Especially while he pretends to be so shock'd at all indecent amours. In the country he us'd to make the maids lock up the turkey cocks every Saturday night, for fear they should gallant the hens on a Sunday.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: O! ridiculous!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Upon my lise, Madam, my sister told me so.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I tell you so, you impudent—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Fy, Charlotte; he only jests with you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P:
How can you be such a monster to stay playing the fool here, when you have more reason to be frighted out of your wits? You don't know perhaps, that
my father declares he'll settle a fortune upon this fellow too.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: 'Tis too true; 'tis not three minutes since he said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Nay, then it is time indeed his eyes were open'd, and give me leave to say, Madam, 'tis only in your power.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: What is't you propose?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why, if this fellow, which I'm sure of, is really in love with you, give him a fair opportunity to declare himself, and leave me to make my advantage of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I should be loath to do a wrong thing—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Dear Madam, it is the only way in the world to ex∣pose him to my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I'll think of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Pray do, Madam; but in the mean time I mut leave you—poor Darnley stays for me at the Smyrna, and will sit upon thorns till I bring him an account of his new rival.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, well, get you gone then; here is my grand∣mother, and after the affront you offer'd this morning to the Doctor, she will not be able to bear the sight of you.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: Old Lady EAMBERT, Young Lady LAMBERT, CHARLOTTE.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: This is kind, Madam; I hope your Ladyship's come to dine with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: No; dont be afraid; only in my way from Tot∣tenham Court, I just call'd to see whether any dread∣ful accident happen'd to the family since I was here last.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Accident! did your Ladyship say?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I shall be sorry, daughter, but not surpriz'd when I hear it; for there are goings on under this roof, that will bring temporal punishments along with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Indeed, Madam, you astonish me!

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: We'll drop the subject, and I beg leave to address myself to you, Miss Charlotte: I see you have a bit of lace there upon your neck, I desire to know what you wear▪it for.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Wear it for, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: In short, I have been at my linen-draper's to day, and have brought you some thick muslin, which I de∣sire you will make handkerchiefs of—for I must tell you that slight covering is indecent, and gives much of∣fence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Indecent, did your Ladyship say?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Yes, Daughter-in-law. Doctor Cantwell com∣plains to me that he cannot sit at table, the sight of her bare neck disturbs him so;—and he's a good man, and knows what indecency is.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Yes, indeed; I believe he does, better than any one in this house.—But you may tell the Doctor from me, Madam, that he is an impudent coxcomb, a puppy, and deserves to have his bones broke.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Fy! Charlotte; fy! He speaks but for your good, and this is the grateful return you make.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Grateful return, Madam!—The Doctor is one of those who start at a feather.—Poor good man; yet he has his vices of the graver sort—

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Come, come; I wish you would follow his pre∣cepts, whose practice is conformable to what he teaches.—Virtuous man!—Above all sensual regards, he considers the world merely as a collection of dirt and pebble-stones.—How has he wean'd me from tem∣poral connections! My heart is now set upon nothing sublunary; and, I thank heaven, I am so insensible to every thing in this limbo of vanity, that I could see you, my son, my daughters, my brothers, my grand∣children, all expire before me; and mind it no more than the going out of so many snuffs of candle.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Upon my word, Madam; it is a very humane dis∣position you have been able to arrive at, and your family is much oblig'd to the Doctor for his instruc∣tions.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, child, I have nothing more to say to you at present; heaven mend you, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: But pray, Madam, stay and dine with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: No, Daughter; I have said it, and you know I ne∣ver tell a lye; but here's my son, if you'll give me leave, I'll stay and speak to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Your Ladyship's time's your own.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: This fellow puts me beyond my patience.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir JOHN LAMBERT, Old Lady LAMBERT, Doctor CANTWELL.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Oh Madam, Madam! I'm glad you're here, to join me in solicitations to the Doctor.—Here is my mother, friend, my mother; a pious woman; you will hear her, more worthy to advise you than I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Alas, the dear good Lady, I will kiss her hand; but what advice can she give me? The riches of the word, Sir, have no charms for me; I am not dazzled with their false glare; and was I, I repeat it, to accept of the trust you want to repose in me, heaven knows, it would only be lest the means should fall into wicked hands, who wou'd not lay it out as I should do, for the glory of heaven, and the good of my neighbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: What is the matter, son?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Nothing, Madam; nothing.—But you were witness how the worthy Colonel treated me this morning—not that I speak it on my own account,—for to be revil'd is my portion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: O the villain! the villain!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Indeed, I did not think he had so hard a nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ah! your charitable heart knows not the rancour that is in his.—His wicked sister too, has been here this moment abusing this good man.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P:
O Sir, 'tis plain; 'tis plain; your whole family are in a combination against m—your son and daughter hate me; they think I stand between them and your favour; and indeed it is not fit I should do so; for, fall'n as they are, they are still your children,
and I an alien, an intruder, who ought in conscience to retire and heal those unhappy wretches.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: See, if the good man does not wipe his eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Oh heavens! the thought of their ingratitude wounds me to the quick—but I'll remove this eye∣sore—here Charles

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: For goodness sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Bring me that writing I gave you to lay up this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Make haste, good Charles; it shall be sign'd this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Not for the world, Sir John—every minute tends to corroborate my last intentions—I must not, will not take it, with the curses of your children.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: But, consider, Doctor—shall my wicked son then be heir to my lands, before repentance has intitled him to favour—No, let him depend upon you, whom he has wrong'd; perhaps, in time, he may reflect on his father's justice, and be reconcil'd to your reward∣ed virtues.—If heav'n should at last reclaim him, in you, I know, he still would find a fond forgiving father.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: The imagination of so bless'd an hour softens me to a tenderness I can't support!

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Oh! the dear good man!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: With regard to my daughter, Doctor, you know, she is not wrong'd by it; because, if she prove not obstinate, she may still be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Yes, but the perverse wretch slights the blessing you propose for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: We must allow, Madam, female modesty a time, which often takes the likeness of distaste: the com∣mands of your good son might too suddenly surprize her—maids must be gently dealt with—and, might I humbly advise—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Any thing you will—you shall govern me and her.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Then, Sir, abate of your authority, and let the matter rest a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Suppose we were to get my wife to speak to her; women will often hear from their own sex, what, sometimes, even from the man they like, will startle them▪

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Then, with your permission, Sir, I will take an opportunity of talking to my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: She's now in her dressing-room; I'll go and prepare her for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: You are too good to me, Sir—too bountiful.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV2.STAGE: Old Lady LAMBERT, Doctor CANTWELL, and SEYWARD introducing MAW-WORM.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Sir, Mr. Maw-worm is without, and would be glad to be permitted to speak to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Oh! pray, Doctor, admit him; I have not seen Mr. Maw-worm this great while; he's a pious man, tho' in an humble estate; desire the worthy creature to walk in—How do you do, Mr. Maw-worm?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: Thank your Ladyship's axing—I'm but deadly poorish, indeed; the world and I can't agree—I have got the books, Doctor—and Mrs. Grunt bid me give her service to you, and thanks you for the eigh∣teen pence.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Hush, friend Maw-worm! not a word more; you know I hate to have my little charities blaz'd about: a poor widow, Madam, to whom I sent my mite.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Give her this. [Offers a purse, to Maw-worm.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I'll take care it shall be given to her. [Puts it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: But what's the matter with you, Mr. Maw-worm?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: I don't know what's the matter with me—I'm a breaking my heart—I thinks its a sin, to keep a shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why, if you think it a sin, indeed—pray what's your business?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: We deals in grocery, tea, small-beer, charcoal, butter, brick-dust, and the like.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well; you must consult with your friendly direc∣tor here.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: I wants to go a preaching.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Do you?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: I'm almost sure, I have had a call.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ay!

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: I have made several sermons already, I does them extrumpery, because I can't write; and now the de∣ils in our alley says as how, my head's turn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ay, devils, indeed—but don't you mind them.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: No, I don't—I rebukes them, and preaches to them, whether they will or not. We lets our house in lodgings to single men; and, sometimes, I gets them together, with one or two of the neighbours, and makes them all cry.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Did you ever preach in public?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: I got up, on Kennington Common, the last review day; but the boys threw brick-bats at me, and pinn'd crackers to my tail; and I have been afraid to mount ever since.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Do you hear this, Doctor! throw brick-bats at him, and pin crackers to his tail; can these things be stood by?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: I told them so—says I, I does nothing clande∣cently; I stand here contagious to his Majesty's guards, and, I charges you upon your apparels, not to milist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: And it had no effect.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: No more, than if I spoke to so many postesses; but if he advises me to go a preaching, and quit my shop, I'll make an excressance farther into the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: An excursion, you would say.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: I am but a sheep, but my bleatings shall be heard afar off, and that sheep shall become a shepherd; nay, if it be only, as it were, a shepherd's dog, to bark the stray lambs into the fold.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: He wants method, Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, but there is matter; and I despise not the ignorant.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: He's a saint—'till I went after him, I was little better than the devil; my conscience was tann'd with sin, like a piece of neat's leather, and had no more feeling than the soal of my shoe; always a roving after fantastical delights; I us'd to go, every Sunday evening, to the Three-hats at Islington; it's a public-house; may-hap, your Ladyship may know it: I was a great lover of skittles too, but now I can't bear them; so I sits at home all day, and does nothing but read, and sing hymns, and talk against the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: What a blessed reformation!

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: I believe, Doctor, you never know'd as how I was instigated one of the stewards of the reforming society. I conwicted a man of five oaths, as last Thursday was a se'nnight, at the Pewter-platter in the Bo∣rough; and another of three, while he was playing trap-ball in St. George's Fields: I bought this waistcoat out of my share of the money.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: But, how do you mind your business?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: We have lost almost all our customers; because I keeps extorting them whenever they come into the shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: And how do you live?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P:
Better than ever we did: while we were worldly∣minded, my wife and I (for I am married to as likely a woman as you shall see in a thousand) could hardly make things do at all; but since this good man has brought us into the road of the righteous, we have
always plenty of every thing; and my wife goes as well-dress'd as a gentlewoman—we have had a child too.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Merciful!

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: And between you and me, Doctor, I believe Susy's breeding again.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Thus it is, Madam; I am constantly told, tho' I can hardly believe it, a blessing follows, wherever I come.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: And yet, if you would hear how the neighbours reviles my wife; saying, as how she sets no store by me, because we have words now and then; but, as I says, if such was the case, would ever she have cut me down that there time, as I was melancholy, and she found me hanging behind the door; I don't believe there's a wife in the parish would have done so by her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I believe, 'tis near dinner time; and Sir John will require my attendance.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: Oh! I am troublesome—nay, I only come to you, Doctor, with a message from Mrs. Grunt. I wish your Ladyship heartily and heartily farewell; Doc∣tor, a good day to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Mr. Maw-worm, call to me sometime this after∣noon; I want to have a little private discourse with you; and, pray, my service to your spouse.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: I will, Madam; you are a malefactor to all good∣ness; I'll wait upon your Ladyship; I will, indeed: [Going returns] Oh, Doctor, that's true; Susy desired me to give her kind love and respects to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Madam, if you please, I will lead you into the par∣lour.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: No, Doctor, my coach waits at the door; I only call'd about the business you know of, and partly, indeed, to see how you did, after the usage you had met with; but, I have struck the wretch out of my will for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Charles, you may lay those papers bye again, but in some place where you'll easily find them; for I be∣lieve, we shall have occasion for them some time this afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: I'll take care, Sir.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV2.STAGE: SEYWARD, BETTY, and then CHAR∣LOTTE, with a book.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Occasion for them this afternoon! then there's no time to be lost; the coast is clear, and this is her chamber—what's the matter with me—the thought of speaking to her throws me into a disorder—there's no body within, I believe; I'll knock again—Is your Lady busy.

SP.SPEAKER: BETTY.
SP.P: I believe she's only reading, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Will you do me the favour to let her know, if she is at leisure, I beg to speak with her upon some ear∣nest business.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Who is that?

SP.SPEAKER: BETTY.
SP.P: She's here—Mr. Seyward, Madam, desires to speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P:
O, your servant, Mr. Seyward—here, take this odious Homer, and lay him up again, he tires me; how could the blind wretch make such an horrid fuss about a fine woman, for so many volumes together,
and give us no account of her amours—you have read him, I suppose, in the Greek, Mr. Seyward?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Not lately, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: But do you so violently admire him now?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: The critics say, he has his beauties, Madam; but Ovid has been always my favourite.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Ovid; O, he's ravishing!

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: So art thou, to madness.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord! how could one do to learn Greek? were you a great while about it?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: It has been half the business of my life, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: That's cruel now; then you think one coudn't be mistress of it in a month or two.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Not easily, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: They tell me, it has the softest tone for love of any language in the world; I fancy, I could soon learn it.—I know two words of it already.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, what are they?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Stay, let me see—O—ay—Zoe kai Psuche.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: I hope you know the English of them, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O, lud! I hope there is no harm in it; I'm sure, I heard the Doctor say it to my Lady—pray, what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P:
You must first imagine, Madam, a tender lover gazing on his mistress; and then, indeed, they have
a softness in them, as thus—Zoe kai psuche; my life! my soul!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O, the impudent young rogue! how his eyes spoke too! what the duce can he want with me?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: I have startled her!—she muses!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, but your business with me, Mr. Seyward? you have something of love in your head, I'll lay my life on't.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: I never yet durst own it, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Why; what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: My story is too melancholy to entertain a mind so much at ease as yours.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Oh, I love melancholy stories of all things▪ pray, how long have you liv'd with your uncle, Mr. Sey∣ward?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: With Doctor Cantwell, I suppose you mean, Ma∣dam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: He's no uncle of mine, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You surprise me! not your uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: No, Madam; but that's not the only character the Doctor assumes, to which he has no right.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord! I am concern'd for you.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: So you would, Madam, if you knew all.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I am already; but if there are any further particu∣lars of your story, pray let me hear them; and should any services be in my power, I am sure you may com∣mand them.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: My father, Madam, was the younger branch of a genteel family in the North, his name Trueman—but dying, while I was yet in my infancy, I was left wholly dependent on my mother—a woman really pious and well meaning, but.—In short, Madam, Doctor Cantwell fatally got acquainted with her, and, as he is now your father's bosom counsellor, soon became hers; for his hypocrisy had so great an effect on her weak spirit, that he entirely led and manag'd her at his pleasure.—She died, Madam, when I was but eight years old; and then I was, indeed, left an orphan.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Poor creature!—Lord! I cannot bear it!

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: She left Doctor Cantwell her sole heir and execu∣tor—but I must do her the justice to say, I believe it was in the confirmation, that he would take care of, and do justice to me; who, young as I was, I yet remember to have heard her recommend to him, on her death-bed; and, indeed, he has so far taken care of me, that he sent me to a seminary abroad; and for these three years last past; has kept me with him.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Oh! heavens! but, why have you not strove to do yourself justice?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P:
Thrown so young into his power, as I was—un∣known and friendless, but thro' his means; to whom could I apply for succour?—Nay, Madam, I will confess, that, on my return to England, I was, at first, tainted with his enthusiastic notions myself; and, for some time, as much impos'd upon by him, as others; till, by degrees, as he found it necessary to make use
of, or totally discard me (which last he did not think prudent to do), he was obliged to unveil himself to me, in his proper colours—And, I believe, I can inform you of some parts of his private character, that may be the means of detecting one of the wickedest impostors that ever practis'd upon credulity.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: But how has the wretch dared to treat you?—

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: In his ill and insolent humours, Madam, he has sometimes the presumption to tell me, that I am the object of his charity; and, I own, Madam, that I am humbled, in my own opinion, by his having drawn me into a connivance at some actions, which I can't look back on without horror!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Indeed, you can't tell how I pity you, and depend upon it, if it be possible to serve you, by getting you out of the clutches of this monster, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Once more, Madam, let me assure you, that your generous inclination would be a consolation to me in the worst misfortunes; and, even in the last moment of painful death, would give my heart a joy.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord! the poor unfortunate boy loves me too—what shall I do with him—pray, Mr. Seyward, what paper's that you have got in your hand?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Another instance of the conscience, and gratitude, which animates our worthy Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You frighten me! pray, what is the purport of it? It is neither sign'd nor seal'd:

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: No, Madam; therefore▪ to prevent it, by this time∣ly notice, was my business here with you: your fa∣ther gave it the Doctor first, to shew his council, who, having approved it, I understand, this evening it will be executed.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: But what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: It grants to Doctor Cantwell, in present, four hun∣dred pounds per Annum, of which, this very house is part; and, at your father's death, invests him in the whole remainder of his freehold estate.—For you, indeed, there is a charge of four thousand pounds upon it, provided you marry with the Doctor's con∣sent; if not, 'tis added to my Lady's jointure; but your brother, Madam, is, without conditions, utterly disinherited.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I am confounded!—what will become of us? my father now I find, was serious—O, this insinuating Hypocrite—let me see—ay—I will go this minute.—Sir, dare you trust this in my hands for an hour only.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Any thing to serve you—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Hark! they ring to dinner; pray, Sir, step in; say I am oblig'd to dine abroad; and whisper one of the footmen to get a chair immediately; then do you take a proper occasion to slip out after me to Mr. Double's chambers in the Temple; there I shall have time to talk further with you.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A Dressing-room, with glass, table, and chairs—CHARLOTTE, with BETTY, taking off her cloak, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: HAS any one been to speak with me, Betty?

SP.SPEAKER: BETTY.
SP.P: Only Mr. Darnley, Madam; he said, he would call again, and bid his servant stay below, to give him notice when you came home.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You don't know what he wanted?

SP.SPEAKER: BETTY.
SP.P: No, Madam; he seem'd very uneasy at your being abroad.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, go and lay up those things; ten to one but his wise head now has found out something to be jealous of: if he lets me see it, I shall be sure to make him infinitely easy—here he comes.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: CHARLOTTE, DARNLEY.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Your humble servant, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Your servant, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: You have been abroad, I hear?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Yes, and now I am come home you see.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: You seem to turn upon my words, Madam; is there any thing particular in them?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: As much as there is in my being abroad, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Might not I say you had been abroad, without giving offence?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: And might not I as well say, I was come home, without your being so grave upon't?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Do you know any thing should make me grave?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I know if you are so, I am the worst person in the world you can possibly shew it to.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Nay, I don't suppose you do any thing you won't justify.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O, then I find I have done something you think I can't justify.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I don't say that, neither; perhaps, I am in the wrong, in what I have said; but I have been so often used to ask pardon for your being in the wrong, that I am resolv'd henceforth never to rely on the insolent evidence of my own senses.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You don't know now, perhaps, that I think this pretty smart speech of yours is very dull; but, since that's a fault you can't help, I will not take it ill: come now, be as sincere on your side, and tell me se∣riously—Is not what real business I had abroad the very thing you want to be made easy in?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: If I thought you would make me easy, I would own it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Now we come to the point.—To-morrow morning, then, I give you my word, to let you know it all; till when, there is a necessity for it's being a secret; and I insist upon your believing it.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: But pray, Madam, what am I to do with my pri∣vate imagination in the mean time? that is not in my power to confine; and sure you won't be offended, if, to avoid the tortures that may give me, I beg you'll trust me with the secret now.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Don't press me; for positively I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Can't had been a kinder term—is my disquiet of so little moment to you?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Of none, while your disquiet dares not trust the assurances I have given you. If you expect I should confide in you for life, don't let me see you dare not take my word for a day; and, if you are wise, you'll think so fair a trial a favour.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: If you intend it such—it is a favour; if not, 'tis something—so—come, let's wave the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: With all my heart: Have you seen my brother lately?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Yes, Madam; and he tells me, it seems, the Doctor is the man your father has resolv'd upon.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: 'Tis so; nay, and what will more surprize you, he leaves me only to the choice of him, or of no fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: And may I, without offence, beg leave to know what resolution you have taken upon't.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I have not taken any; I do not know what to do; what would you advise me to?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I advise you to? nay, you are in the right to make it a question.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: He says he'll settle all his estate upon him too.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: O take it; take it, to be sure; it's the fittest match in the world; you can't do a wiser thing certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: 'Twill be as wise, at least, as the method you take to prevent it.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Is't possible? how can you torture me with this indifference?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Why do you insult me with such a bare-fac'd jea∣lousy?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Is it a crime to be concern'd for what becomes of you? has not your father openly declar'd against me, in favour of another? how is it possible, at such a time, not to have a thousand fears? what? tho' they are all false and groundless, are they not still the effect of love, alarmed, and anxious to be satisfied? I have an heart that cannot bear disguises; but when 'tis griev'd, in spite of me, will shew it—pray pardon me—but when I am told you went out in the utmost hurry with some writings to a lawyer, and took the Doctor's nephew with you; ev'n in the very hour your father had propos'd him as an husband; what am I to think? can I? must I suppose my senses fail me? if I have eyes, have ears, and have an heart, must it be still a crime to think I see and hear?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, I own, it looks ill-natur'd now, not to shew him some concern—but then, this jealousy—I must, and will get the better of.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Speak, Charlotte; is still my jealousy a crime?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P:
If you still insist on't, as a proof of love, then I must tell you, Sir, 'tis of that kind that only slighted hearts are pleas'd with. The fact you charge me
with, is true; I have been abroad; but let appearan∣ces be ever so strong, while there is a possibility, that what I have done may be innocent, I won't bear a look that tells me to my face, you dare suspect me. If you have doubts, why don't you satisfy them before you see me? Can you suppose I am to stand confound∣ed, like a criminal before you? Come, come, there's nothing shews so low a mind, as those grave and in∣solent jealousies.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: However, Madam, mine you won't find so low as you imagine; and, since I see your tyranny arises from your mean opinion of me, 'tis time to be myself, and disavow your power; you use it now beyond my bear∣ing; not only impose on me, to disbelieve my senses, but do it with such an imperious air, as if my manly reason were your slave; and this despicable frame that follows you, durst shew no signs of life but what you vouchsafe to give it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You are in the right:—go on—suspect me still—believe the worst you can—'tis all true—I don't jus∣tify myself.—Why do you trouble me with your complaints? if you are master of that manly reason you have boasted, give me a manly proof of it▪ at once resume your liberty; despise me; go off in triumph now; and let me see you scorn the woman, whose overbearing falsehood would insult your senses.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Is this the end of all then? and, are those tender protestations you have made me (for such I thought them), when, with a kind reluctance, you gave me something more than hope?—what all?—O, Char∣lotte!—all come to this!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O, lud! I am growing silly; if I hear on, I shall tell him every thing; 'tis but another struggle, and I shall conquer it.—So, you are not gone, I see.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Do you then wish me gone, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Your manly reason will direct you.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: This is too much—my heart can bear no more!—What, am I rooted here?

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: DARNLEY, CHARLOTTE, SEYWARD.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: At last, I am relieved.—Well, Mr. Seyward, is it done?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: I did not stir from the desk till it was entirely fi∣nished.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Where's the original?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: This is it, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Very well; that you know you must keep; but come, we must lose no time; we will examine this in the next room—now I feel for him.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: This is not to be borne—Pray, Mr. Charles, what private business have you with that Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I must know, young man.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Not quite so young, but I can keep a secret, and a Lady's too—you'll excuse, me, Sir!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: DARNLEY, Colonel LAMBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P:
'Sdeath! I shall be laugh'd at by every body—I shall run distracted—this young fellow should re∣pent
his pertness, did not this house protect him—this is Charlotte's contrivance to distract me—but—but what? Oh! I have love enough to bear this, and ten times as much.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: How now, Frank! what, in raptures?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Prythee—I am unfit to talk with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: What? is Charlotte in her airs again?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I know not what she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Do you know where she is?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Retir'd this moment to her chamber with the young fellow there—the Doctor's nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why you are not jealous of the Doctor, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Perhaps she'll be less reserv'd to you, and tell you wherein I have mistaken her.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Poor Frank; every plot I lay upon my sister's incli∣nation for you, you are sure to ruin by your own un∣fortunate conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I own I have too little temper, and too much real passion, for a modish lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Come, come; make yourself easy once more; I'll undertake for you: if you'll fetch a cool turn in the Park upon Constitution Hill, in less than half an hour I'll come to you.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Dear Tom! you are a friend, indeed!—I have a thousand things—but you shall find me there.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: Colonel LAMBERT, CHARLOTTE, and SEYWARD, who goes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: How now, sister? what have you done to Darnley? the poor fellow looks as if he had kill'd your parrot.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Psha! you know him well enough; I've only been setting him a love lesson; it a little puzzles him to get thro' it at first, but he'll know it all by to-morrow—you will be sure to be in the way, Mr. Seyward.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Madam, you may depend upon me; I have my full instructions.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: O ho! here's the business then; and it seems Darnley was not to be trusted with it; ha! ha! and prythee, what is this mighty secret that is trans∣acting between Seyward and you?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: That's what he would have known, indeed; but you must know, I don't think it proper to let you tell him neither, for all your fly manner of asking.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Pray take your own time, dear Madam; I am not in haste to know, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, but hold; on second thoughts, you shall know part of this affair between Seyward and me; nay, I give you leave to tell it Darnley too, on some conditions; 'tis true, I did design to have surpriz'd you—but now—my mind's alter'd, that's enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ay, for any mortal's satisfaction—but here comes my Lady.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV2.STAGE: CHARLOTTE, Colonel LAMBERT, Lady LAMBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Away, away, Colonel, and Charlotte, both of you, away this instant.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: What's the matter, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I am going to put the Doctor to his trial, that's all. I have considered the proposal you made me to-day, Colonel, and am convinc'd it ought not to be delay∣ed an instant: so just now, as your father was com∣pos'd in the arm chair to his afternoon's nap, I told the Doctor, in a half-whisper, that I should be glad to have a word in private with him here; and he said he would wait upon me presently.
