You must know, Charlotte, Sir John has been pressing me to speak to you, in his favour, and has desir'd me to hear what the Doctor had to say upon that subject; but must I play a traiterous part now, and instead of per∣suading you to the Doctor, persuade the Doctor a∣gainst you?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Dear Madam, why not? one moment's truce with the prude I beg of you; don't startle at his first decla∣ration, but let him go on, till he shews the very bot∣tom of his ugly heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I warrant you, I'll give a good account of him—but, as I live, here he comes!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Come, then, brother, you and I will be comode, and steal off.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV2.STAGE: Lady LAMBERT, Doctor CANTWELL.
[The Colonel listening.]

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Here I am, Madam, at your Ladyship's command; how happy am I that you think me worthy—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Please to sit, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Well, but, dear Lady, ha! You can't conceive the joyousness I feel at this so much desir'd interview. Ah! ah! I have a thousand friendly things to say to you; and how stands your precious health? is your naughty cold abated yet? I have scarce clos'd my eyes these two nights with my concern for you, and every watchful interval has sent a thousand sighs and prayers to heaven for your recovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Your charity is too far concern'd for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Ah! Don't say so; don't say so: You merit more than mortal man can do for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Indeed you over-rate me.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I speak it from my heart; indeed, indeed, indeed, I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: O dear! You hurt my hand, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Impute it to my zeal, and want of words for ex∣pression: Precious soul! I would not harm you for the world; no, it would be the whole business of my life—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: But to the affair I would speak to you about.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Ah, thou heavenly woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Your hand need not be there, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I was admiring the softness of this silk.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ay, but I'm ticklish.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: They are indeed come to prodigious perfection in all manufactures: How wonderful is human art! Here it disputes the prize with nature: that all this soft and gaudy lustre should be wrought from the labours of a poor worm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: But our business, Sir, is upon another subject: Sir John informs me, that he thinks himself under no obligations to Mr. Darnley, and therefore resolves to give his Daughter to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Such a thing has been mention'd, Madam; but, to deal sincerely with you, that is not the happiness I sigh after; there is a soft and serious excellence for me, very different from what your step-daughter possesses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, Sir, pray be sincere, and open your heart to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Open my heart! can you then, sweet Lady, be yet a stranger to it? Has no action of my life been able to inform you of my real thoughts? I hope you imagine not that it was from ill-will, or on any account but yours, that I urg'd Sir John to restrain your assem∣blies and visits: No, blessed creature! It proceeded from a zealous transport: I could not bear to see the gay, the young, and the impertinent, daily crowd∣ing round you, without a certain grudge; I might say, envy—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, Sir; I take all this as I suppose you intend it, for my good and spiritual welfare.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Indeed, I mean't you cordial service.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I dare say you did: you are above the low moment∣ary views of this world.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Why, I should be so; and yet, alas! I find this mortal cloathing of my soul is made like other mens, of sensual flesh and blood, and has it's frailties.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: We all have those, but yours are well corrected by your divine and virtuous contemplations.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Alas, Madam, my heart is not of stone: I may re∣sist, call all my prayers, my fastings, tears and penance to my aid; but yet, I am not an angel; I am still but man; and virtue may strive, but nature will be upper∣most. I love you then, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Hold, Sir; you've said enough to put you in my power. Suppose I now should let my husband, your enefactor, know the favour you design him?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: You cannot be so cruel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Nor will, on this condition: That instantly you re∣nounce all claim and title to Charlotte, and use your utmost interest with Sir John, to give her, with her full fortune, to Mr. Darnley.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: Lady LAMBERT, Doctor CANTWELL, Colonel LAMBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Villain! Monster! Perfidious and ungrateful tray∣tor! Your hypocrisy, your false zeal is discovered; and I am sent here by the hand of insulted heaven, to lay you open to my father, and expose you to the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: O unthinking Colonel!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, Sir, what have you to say for yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I have nothing to say to you, Colonel, nor for you—but you shall have my prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why, you profligate Hypocrite! do you think to carry off your villainy with that sanctified air?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I know not what you mean, Sir; I have been in discourse here with my good Lady, by permission of your worthy Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Dog! did my Father desire you to talk of love to my Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Call me not dog, Colonel: I hope we are both bro∣ther Christians.—Yes, I will own I did beg leave to talk to her of love; for alas, I am but a man; yet if my passion for your dear sister, which I cannot con∣troul, be sinful—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Your noise, I perceive, is bringing up Sir John; manage with him as you will at present: I will with∣draw, for I have an after-game to play, which may yet put this wretch effectually into our power.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir JOHN LAMBERT. Colonel LAMBERT, Doctor CANTWELL.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: What uproar is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P:
Nothing, Sir; nothing; only a little broil of the good Doctor's here—You are well rewarded for your kindnesses; and he would fain pay it back with triple interest to your wise: in short, Sir, I took him here in
the very fact of making a criminal declaration of lo to my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Why, why, Sir John, would you not let me leave your house? I knew some dreadful method would be taken to drive me hence—O be not angry, good Colo∣nel; but, indeed, and indeed, you use me cruelly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Horrible, wicked creature!—Doctor, let me hear it from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Alas, Sir! I am in the dark as much as you; but it should seem, for what purpose he best knows, your son hid himself somewhere hereabouts; and while I was talking to my Lady, rush'd in upon us—you know the subject, Sir, on which I was to entertain her; and I might speak of my love for your daughter with more warmth than, perhaps, I ought; which the Colonel over-hearing, he might possibly imagine I was addressing my Lady herself; for I will not sus∣pect; no, the Lord forbid! I will not suspect that he would intentionally forge a falsehood to dishonour me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Now, vile detractor of all virtue! is your outrage∣ous malice confounded—what he tells you is true; he has been talking to my Lady by my consent; and what he said, he said by my orders—good man, be not concerned; for I see thro' their vile design—Here, thou curse of my life, if thou art not lost to con∣science, and all sense of honour, repair the injury you have attempted, by confessing your rancour, and throwing yourself at his feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Oh, Sir John! for my sake—I will throw myself at the Colonel's feet; nay, if that will please him, he shall tread on my neck.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: What, mute, defenceless, harden'd in thy malice?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I scorn the imputation, Sir; and with the same re∣peated honesty avow (however cunningly he may have devised this gloss) that you are deceiv'd—what I tell you, Sir, is true—these eyes, these ears, were witnesses of his audacious love, without the mention of my sister's name; directly, plainly, grossly tending to abuse the honour of your bed▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Villain! this instant leave my sight, my house, my family, for ever; wife, children, servants, all are leagu'd against this pious man, and think to weary by groundless clamours, to discard him; but all shall not do. Your malice on your own wicked heads; to me, it but the more endears him.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Doctor, you have triumph'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Wretch! leave my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Hold, good Sir John: I am now recovered from my surprise; let me then be an humble mediator—on my account this must not be—I grant it possible, your son loves me not, but you must grant it too as possible, he might mistake me; to accuse me then was but the error of his virtue; you ought to love him, thank him, for such watchful care.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT
SP.P: O miracle of charity!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Come, come; such breaches must not be betwixt so good a son and father; forget, forgive, embrace him, cherish him, and let me bless the hour I was the occa∣sion of so sweet a reconcilement.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Hear this, perverse and reprobate! Oh! could'st thou wrong such more than mortal virtue?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Wrong him? the harden'd impudence of this painted charity—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Peace, graceless infidel!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: No, Sir; though I would hazard life to gain you from the clutches of that wretch, could die to recon∣cile my duty to your favour; yet, on the terms his vil∣lainy offers, it is merit to refuse it—I glory in the dis∣grace your errors give me—but, Sir, I'll trouble you no more; to-day is his, to-morrow may be mine.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE X.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir JOHN LAMBERT, Doctor CANTWELL.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Come, my friend; we'll go this instant, and sign the settlement.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Sir, I now attend you, and take it without scruple: yes, you shall; since it is your good pleasure, make this settlement in my favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: I will, Doctor; I will; for that wretch ought to be punish'd, who, I now see, is incorrigible, and giv'n over to perdition.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: And do you think I take your estate with such views?—No, Sir,—I receive it that I may have an opportunity to rouse his mind to virtue, by shewing him an Instance of the forgiveness of injuries; the re∣turn of good for evil.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: O, my dear friend! my stay, and my guide! I am impatient till the affair is concluded.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: The will of heav'n be done in all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Poor dear man! [Turning to where the Colonel went off.] Oh, reprobate! profligate! harden'd wretch! to use in this manner a person of his sanc∣tity!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT. IV. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A Parlour in Sir JOHN LAMBERT'S House.
CHARLOTTE, SEYWARD.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: YOU were a witness, then?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: I saw it sign'd, seal'd, and deliver'd, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: And all pass'd without the least suspicion?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Sir John sign'd it with such earnestness, and the Doctor receiv'd it with such a seeming reluctance, that neither had the curiosity to examine a line of it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Seyward, whether it succeeds to our ends or not, we have still the same obligations to you. You saw with what a friendly warmth my brother heard your story, and I don't in the least doubt his being able to do something for you.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: What I have done, my duty bound me to; but pray, madam, give me leave, without offence, to ask you one innocent question.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Freely.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Have you never suspected, that in all this affair, I have had some secret stronger motive, than barely duty?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Yes.—But have you been in no apprehensions I should discover that motive?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Pray pardon me; I see, already, I have gone too far.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P:
Not at all, it loses you no merit with me; nor is it in my nature to use any one ill that loves me, unless
I lov'd that one again; then, indeed, there might be danger.—Come, don't look grave; my inclinations to another shall not hinder me paying every one what's due to their merit; I shall, therefore, always think myself obliged to treat your misfortunes, and your modesty, with the utmost tenderness.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Dear Madam, mad as I am, I never hop'd for more.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Then I'll give you a great deal more: and, to shew my particular good opinion of you, I'll do you a favour, Mr. Seyward, I never did any man since I was born.—I'll be sincere with you.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Is it then possible you can have lov'd another, to whom you never were sincere?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Alas! you are but a novice in the passion. Sincerity is a dangerous virtue, and often surfeits what it ought to nourish. Therefore I take more pains to make the man I love believe I slight him, than (if possible) I would to convince you of my esteem and friendship. Nay, I'll do more still; I'll shew you all the good-na∣ture you can desire; you shall make what love to me you please; but then I'll tell you the consequence; I shall certainly be pleas'd with it, and that will flatter you, till I do you a mischief. Now do you think me sincere?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: I scarce consider that; but I'm sure you are agree∣able.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Why, look you there now; do you consider that a woman had as lief be thought agreeable, as handsome; and how can you suppose, from one of your sense, that I am not pleas'd with being told so?

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Was ever temper so enchanting!—Your good opi∣nion is all I aim at.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Ay; but the more I give it you, the better you'll think of me still; and then I must think the better of you again, and then you the better of me, upon that too; and so at last I shall think seriously, and you'll begin to think ill of me. But I hope, Mr. Seyward, your good sense will prevent all this.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: I see my folly, Madam, and blush at my presump∣tion.—Madam, I humbly take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord! how one may live and learn! I could not have believ'd that modesty, in a young fellow, could have been so amiable. And tho' I own there is, I know not what, of dear delight, in indulging one's va∣nity with them; yet, upon serious reflection, we must confess, that truth and sincerity have a thousand charms beyond it.—I believe, I had as good confess all this to Darnley, and e'en make up the bustle with him too;—but then he will so teize one for instances of real inclination.—O Gad!—I can't bear the thought on't;—and yet we must come together too.—Well, Nature knows the way, and so I'll ev'n trust to her for it.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: Lady LAMBERT, CHARLOTTE.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Dear Charlotte! what will become of us! the ty∣ranny of this subtle Hypocrite is insupportable. He has so fortified himself, in Sir John's Opinion, by this last misconduct of your brother, that I begin to lose my usual power with him.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Pray explain, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: In spite of all I could urge, he has consented, that the Doctor shall this minute come, and be his own advocate with you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I'm glad on't; for the beast must come like a beat to the stake. I'm sure he knows I shall bait him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: No matter for that; he presses it, to keep Sir John still blind to his wicked design upon me.—Therefore I come to give you notice, that you might be prepar'd to receive him.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I'm oblig'd to your Ladyship. Our meeting will be a tender scene, no doubt on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: But I think I hear the Doctor coming up stairs.—My dear girl, at any rate, keep your Temper.—I shall expect you in my dressing-room, to tell me the particulars of your conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: He must have a great deal of impudence, to come in this manner to me.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: CHARLOTTE, Doctor CANTWELL, BETTY in∣troducing the Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: BETTY.
SP.P: Doctor Cantwell desires to be admitted, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Let him come in.—Your servant, Sir.—Give us chairs, Betty, and leave the room▪—Sir, there's a seat.—What can the ugly cur say to me! he seems a little puzzled. (Humming a tune).

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Look ye', young lady, I am afraid, notwithstanding your good father's favour, I am not the man you would desire to be alone with upon this occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Your modesty is pleas'd to be in the right.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I'm afraid, notwithstanding all my endeavours to the contrary, that you entertain a bad opinion of me.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: A worse, Sir, of no mortal breathing!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Which opinion is immoveable.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: No rock so firm!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I am afraid, then, it will be a vain pursuit, when I sollicit you, in compliance with my worthy friend's de∣sire, and my own inclinations, to become my partner, in that blessed estate, in which we might be a comfort and support to each other.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I would die, rather than consent to it!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: In other words, you hate me.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Most transcendantly!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Well! there is sincerity at least in your confession: you are not, I see, totally depriv'd of all virtue; tho', I must say, I never could perceive in you but very little.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Oh, fy! you flatter me!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: No; I speak it with sorrow! because you are the daughter of my best friend. But how are we to proceed now; are we to preserve temper?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Oh! never fear me, Sir! I shall not fly out, being convinced, that nothing gives so sharp a point to one's aversion, as good breeding; as, on the contrary, ill manners often hides a secret inclination.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P:
Well, then, young lady, be assured, so far am I from the unchristian disposition of returning injuries, that your antipathy to me causes no hatred in my soul towards you; on the contrary, I would willingly make
you happy, if it may be done, according to my con∣science, with the interest of heaven in view.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Why, I can't see, Sir, how heaven can be any way concern'd in a tansaction between you and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: When you marry any other person, my consent is necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: So I hear, indeed! but pray, Doctor, how could your modesty receive so insolent a power, without put∣ting my poor father out of countenance with your blushes!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I sought it not; but he would croud it in among other obligations. He is good-natur'd; and I foresaw it might serve to pious purposes.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I take it for granted, that you would marry Mr. Darnley. Am I right?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Once in your life, perhaps you may.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Nay, let us be plain. Would you marry him?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You're mighty nice, methinks. Well, I would.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Then I will not consent.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You won't?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: My conscience will not suffer me. I know you to be both luxurious and worldly-minded; and you would squander upon the vanities of the world, those treasures which ought to be better laid out.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Hum!—I believe I begin to conceive you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: If you can think of any project to satisfy my con∣science, I am tractable. You know there is a consi∣derable moiety of your fortune, which goes to my Lady, in case of our disagreement.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: That's enough, Sir.—You think we should have a fellow-feeling in it. At what sum do you rate your concurrence to my inclinations? that settled, I am willing to strike the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: What do you think of half?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: How! two thousand pounds!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Why, you know you gain two thousand pounds; and really the severity of the times for the poor, and my own stinted pittance, which cramps my charities, will not suffer me to require less.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: But how is my father to be brought into this?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Leave that to my management.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: And what security do you expect for the money?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: O! Mr. Darnley is wealthy: when I deliver my consent in writing, he shall lay it me down in bank bills.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: On one proviso tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Name it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: That you immediately tell my father, that you are willing to give up your interest to Mr. Darnley.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P:
Hum!—stay,—I agree to it; but in the mean time, let me warn you, child, not to expect to turn that, or what has now passed between us, to my confusion, by sinis∣ter
constructions, or evil representations to your father▪ I am satisfied of the piety of my own intentions, and care not what the wicked think of them; but force me not to take advantage of Sir John's good opinion of me, in order to shield myself from the consequences of your malice.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O! I shall not stand in my own light: I know your conscience and your power too well, dear Doctor!

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Well, let your Interest sway you. Thank heaven, I am actuated by more worthy motives.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: No doubt on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Farewell! and think me your friend.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: CHARLOTTE, and then Colonel LAMBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: What this fellow's original was, I know not; but by his conscience and cunning, he would make an ad∣mirable Jesuit.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel LAMBERT.
SP.P: Charlotte!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You may come in. Well, I hope you bring me a good account of the Doctor.—What success?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel LAMBERT.
SP.P: All I could wish!—Seyward has given so strong and so fair a detail of his frauds and villainies of every kind, that my Lord Chief Justice made not the least hesita∣tion to grant his warrant; and I have a tipstaff at the next door, when I give the word, to take him.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Why should not you do it immediately?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel LAMBERT.
SP.P:
Have a little patience; I have a farther design in my head.—But pray, Sister, what secret's this, that you
have yet behind in those writings that Seyward brought you?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O! that's what I can't tell you.—But, by the way, what have you done with Darnley? why is not he here?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel LAMBERT.
SP.P: He has been here; but you must excuse him.—I told him how anxious you were about Seyward's affair, and he has taken him with him, in his own coach, to the Attorney General's.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, I own he has gain'd upon me by this.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I am glad to hear that at last. But I must go and let my Lady know what progress we have made in the Doctor's business; because I have something particular to say to her.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV2.STAGE: CHARLOTTE, DARNLEY introduced by a Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Madam, Mr. Darnley.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Desire him to walk in.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: To find you thus alone, Madam, is an happiness I did not expect, from the temper of our last parting.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I should have been as well pleas'd now, to have been thank'd, as reproach'd, for my good-nature; but you will be in the right, find.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Indeed, you take me wrong. I literally mean't, that I was afraid you wou'd not so soon think I had deserv'd this favour.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, then, one of us has been in the wrong, at least.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: 'Twas I, I own it;—more is not in my power: all the amends possible I have made you: my very joy of seeing you has waited; till what you had at heart, un∣ask'd, was perfected for a rival, whom you had so just∣ly compassionated.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Pooh! but why would you say unask'd now? don't you consider your doing it so, is half the merit of the action?—Lord! you have no art; you should have left me to have taken notice of that. Only imagine, now, how kind and handsome an acknowledgment you have rob'd me of.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: And yet how artfully you have paid it. With what a wanton charming ease you play upon my tenderness!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, but were not you silly now?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Come,—you shall not be serious;—you can't be more agreeable.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O! but I am serious.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Then I'll be so.—Do you forgive me all?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Are we friends, Charlotte?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O Lord! but you've told me nothing of poor Sey∣ward.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Must you needs know that, before you answer me?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord! you are never well, till you have talk'd one out of countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Come, I won't be too particular; you shall answer nothing.—Give me but your hand only.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Psha! I won't pull off my glove; not I.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I'll take it as it is then.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord! there, there; eat it, eat it.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: And so I could, by heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O, my glove! my glove! my glove! you are in a perfect storm! Lord! if you make such a rout with one's hand only; what wou'd you do if you had one's heart?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: That's impossible to tell.—But you were asking me of Seyward, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O, ay! that's true. Well, now you are good again.—Come, tell me all that affair, and then you shall see—how I will like you.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: O! that I could thus play with inclination!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Psha! but you don't tell me now.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P:
There is not much to tell;—only this: We met the Attorney General, to whom he has given a very sensi∣ble account of himself, and the Doctor's proceedings.—But, still more fortunate! there happen'd to be a gen∣tleman present, who came from the same part of the country with Seyward, and is well acquainted with his family; and even remembers the circumstance of his mother's death; who promises to be speedy and diligent in his enquiries.—We have been at the Commons to search for her will, but none has been enter'd.—But, as it can be prov'd, she died possessed of eight or ten thousand pounds, the Attorney General seems very clear in his opinion, that, as the Doctor, at the time of the death of Seyward's mother, was intrusted with
her whole affairs, the court of Equity will oblige him to be accountable.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: If Seyward does not recover his fortune, you must absolutely get him a Commission, and bring him into acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Upon my word, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: And shew him to all the women of taste; and I'll have you call him my pretty fellow, too.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I will, indeed!—but hear me—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: You can't conceive, how prettily he makes love.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Not so well as you make your defence, Charlotte.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord! I had forgot, he is to teach me Greek, too.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Trifling tyrant! how long, Charlotte, do you think you can find out new evasions for what I say unto you?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord! you are horrid silly; but, since 'tis love that makes you such a dunce,—poor Darnley! I for∣give you.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV2.STAGE: DARNLEY, CHARLOTTE, and the Colonel, for some time unseen.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: That's kind, however.—But, to compleat my joy, be kinder yet,—and—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O! I can't! I can't!—Lord! did you never ride an horse-match?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Was ever so wild a question?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Because, if you have, it runs in my head, you gal∣lop'd a mile beyond the winning post, to make sure on't.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Now, I understand you. But since you will have me touch every thing so very tenderly, Charlotte, how shall I find proper words to ask you the lover's last necessary question.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: O! there's a thousand points to be adjusted, before that's answer'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Name them this moment then; for, positively, this is the last time of asking.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Psha! who sent for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: I only came to teach you to speak plain English, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Lord! mind your own business; can't you?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: So I will; for I will make you do more of your's in two minutes, than you wou'd have done without me in a twelvemonth. Why, how now! do you think the man's to dangle after your ridiculous airs for ever?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: This is mighty pretty!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: You'll say so on Thursday sen'night, (for let affairs take what turn they will in the family) that's positively your wedding-day.—Nay, you shan't stir.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Was ever such assurance!

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Upon my life, Madam, I'm out of countenance! I don't know how o behave myself.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: No, no; let him go on, only,—this is beyond what ever was known, sure!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ha! ha! if I was to leave you to yourselves, what a coule of pretty out of countenanced figures you wou'd make! humming and hawing, upon the vulgar points of jointure, and pin-money.—Come, come, I know what's proper on both sides; you shall leave it to me.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I had rather Charlotte wou'd name her own terms to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Have you a mind to any thing particular, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Why, sure! what, do you think I'm only to be fill'd out as you please, and sweeten'd and sip'd up like a dish of tea?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why, pray, Madam, when your tea's ready, what have you to do but to drink it?—but you, I suppose, expect a lover's heart, like your lamp, should be always flaming at your elbow; and when it's ready to go out, you indolently supply it with the spirit of contradiction.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: And so you suppose, that your assurance has made an end of this matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Not till you have given him your hand upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: That then would compleat it?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Perfectly.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Why, then, take it, Darnley.—Now, I presume, you are in high triumph, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: No, sister; now you are consistent with that good sense I always thought you mistress of.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: And now I beg we may separate; for our being seen together, at this critical juncture, may give that devil, the Doctor, suspicion of a confederacy, and make him set some engine at work, that we are not aware of.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: It's a very proper caution. Come along, Darnley: nay, you must leave her now, whatever violence you do yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Ay, ay, take him with you, brother—or stay, Darn∣ley; if you please, you may come along with me.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: A parlour in Sir JOHN LAMBERT's house.—DARN∣LEY, CHARLOTTE.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: BUT really, will you stand to the agreement tho', that I have made with the Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Why not? you shall not break your word upon my account, tho' he might be a villain you gave it to.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, I take it as a compliment; not but I have some hopes of getting over it, and justly too: but don't let me tell you now, I love to surprize—Tho' you shall know all, if you desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: No, Charlotte; I don't want the secret: I am satis∣fied in your inclination to trust me.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Well, then I'll keep the secret, only to shew you that you may, upon occasion, trust me with one.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: But, pray, has the Doctor yet given you any proof of his having declin'd his interest to your father?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Yes; he told me just now, he had brought him to pause upon it, and does not question in two days to compleat it: but desires, in the mean time, you will be ready and punctual with the premium.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Suppose I should talk with Sir John myself? 'tis true he has slighted me of late.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: No matter—Here he comes—This may open ano∣ther scene of action to that I believe my brother's pre∣paring for.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir JOHN LAMBERT, Lady LAMBERT, DARN∣LEY, CHARLOTTE.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Mr. Darnley, I am glad I have met with you here.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I have endeavour'd twice to-day, Sir, to pay my re∣spects to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Sir, I'll be plain with you—I went out to avoid you; but where the welfare of a child is concern'd, you must not take it ill if we don't stand upon cere∣mony—However, since I have reason now to be more in temper than perhaps I was at that time, I should be glad to talk with you.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I take it as a favour, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: You must allow, Mr. Darnley, that conscience is the rule which every honest man ought to walk by.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: 'Tis granted, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Then give me leave to tell you, Sir, that giving you my daughter, would be to act against that conscience I pretend to, while I thought you an ill-liver; and con∣sequently the same tie obliges me to bestow her on a better man—

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Well, but, Sir; to come to the point. Suppose the Doctor (whom I presume you design her for) actually consents to give me up his interest?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: But why do you suppose, Sir, he will give up his in∣terest?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I only judge from what your daughter tells me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: My daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: I appeal to her.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: And I appeal even to yourself, Sir—Has not the Doctor, just now, in the garden, spoke in favour of Mr. Darnley to you? Nay, pray, Sir, be plain; because more depends on that, than you can easily imagine or believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: What senseless insinuation have you got into your head now?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Be so kind, Sir, first to answer me, that I may be better able to inform you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, I own he has declin'd his interest in favour of Mr. Darnley; but I must tell you, Madam, he did it in so modest, so friendly, so good-natur'd, so conscien∣tious a manner, that I now think myself more than ever bound in honour to espouse him.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: But now, Sir, (only for argument's sake) Suppose I could prove that all this seeming virtue was artificial; that his regard for Mr. Darnley was neither founded upon modesty, friendship, good-nature, nor con∣science: or, in short, that he has, like a villain, bar∣ter'd, bargain'd, to give me to Mr. Darnley, for half the four thousand pounds you valued his consent at.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: It is impious to suppose it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Then, Sir, from what principle must you suppose that I accuse him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: From an obstinate prejudice to all that's good and virtuous.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: That's too hard, Sir. But, the worst your opi∣nion can provoke me to, is to marry Mr. Darnley, without either his consent or yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: What do you brave me, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: No, Sir; but I scorn a lie; and will so far vindicate my integrity, as to insist on your believing me; if not, as a child you abandon, I have a right to throw my∣self into other arms for protection.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Dear Charlotte, how your spirit charms me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: I am confounded. These tears cannot be counter∣feit; nor can this be true.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear, I fear it is. Give me leave to ask you one question. In all our mutual course of hap∣piness, have I ever yet deceived you with a falshood?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Would you then believe me, should I accuse him even of crimes which virtue blushes but to mention?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: To what extravagance would you drive me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I would before have undeceiv'd you, when his late artifice turned the honest duty of your son into his own reproach and ruin; but knowing then your temper was inaccessible, I durst not offer it.—But suppose I should be able to let you see his villainy, make him re∣peat his odious love to me in your own hearing, at once throw off the mask, and shew the barefac'd tray∣tor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Is it possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: But then, Sir, I must prevail on you to descend to the poor shifts we are reduced to.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: All; to any thing, to ease me of my doubts: make me but witness of this fact, and I shall soon accuse my∣self, and own my folly equal to his baseness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Observe, then, they that set toils for beasts of prey—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Place me where you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Behind that screen you may easily conceal yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Be it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Mr. Darnley, shall we beg your leave? and you, Charlotte, take the least suspected way to send the Doctor to me directly.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I have a thought will do it, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Oh Charlotte! Oh Mr. Darnley!

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Have but resolution, Sir, and fear nothing.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: Lady LAMBERT, Sir JOHN LAMBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Now, Sir, you are to consider what a desperate dis∣ease I have undertaken to cure: therefore, be sure keep close and still; and, when the proof is full, appear at your discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Fear not; I will conform myself—Yet be not angry, my love, if in a case like this, where I should not be∣lieve even him accusing you; be not angry, I say, if I have also charity enough to hope you may yet be de∣ceived in what you charge him with, till the evidence of my own senses assure me of the contrary.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: 'Tis just.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Hark! I think I hear him coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Now, my dear, remember your promise to have pa∣tience.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Rely upon't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: To your post then.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: If this be truth, what will the world come to!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: Lady LAMBERT, Doctor CANTWELL, with a book.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Madam, your woman tells me, that being here, and alone, you desir'd to speak with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I did, Sir—but, that we may be sure we are alone, pray shut the outward door, and see that passage be clear too—another surprize might ruin us—is all safe?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I have taken care, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: But I am afraid I interrupt your meditations?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: No, Madam, no; I was only looking over some pious exhortations here, for the use of a society of chosen brethren.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ah, Doctor! what have you done to me? the trouble of my mind, since our last unfortunate conference, is not to be express'd. You, indeed, discovered to me, what perhaps, for my own peace, 'twere better I had never been acquainted with; but I had not sufficient time to lay my heart open to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Whither, Madam, would you lead me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I have been uneasy too, not knowing how far you might mistake my behaviour on the last accident that happen'd; but I was really so shock'd, so terrified, I knew not what I was doing: only had I join'd in your defence against the Colonel, it would have been evi∣dent I was his enemy, and I have uses for his friend∣ship. Silence, therefore, was my only prudent part; and I knew your credit with Sir John needed no sup∣port.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Let me presume then to hope, that what I did, you judge was self-defence, and pure necessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: And, perhaps, after all, the accident was lucky; for Sir John, in order to obviate any ill constructions that may be put upon it, insists now that we should be more together, to let the world see his confidence in us both. This relieves us from restraint, and I now dare tell you—but no—I won't—

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: But why, Madam? let me beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: No—besides—what need you ask me—

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Ah! do not endeavour to decoy my foolish heart, too apt to flatter itself. You cannot, sure, think kindly of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, well; I would have you imagine so.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Besides, may I not with reason suspect, that this ap∣parent goodness is but artifice, a shadow of compliance, meant only to persuade me from your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Methinks this doubt of me seems rather founded on your settled resolution not to resign her. 'Tis she, I find, is your substantial happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Oh that you could but fear I thought so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I am convinc'd of it. I can assure you, Sir, I should have saved you this trouble, had I known how deeply you were engaged to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Tears—then I must believe you—but indeed you wrong me. To prove my innocence, it is not an hour since I press'd Sir John to give Charlotte to young Darnley.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Mere artifice. You knew that modest resignation would make Sir John warmer in your interest.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: No, indeed, indeed. I had other motives, which you may hereafter be made acquainted with, and will con∣vince you—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, Sir; now I'll give you leave to guess the rea∣son why, at our last meeting, I press'd you so warmly to resign Charlotte.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Ah dear! ah dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: You cannot blame me for having opposed your hap∣piness, when my own, perhaps, depended upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Spare me, spare me; you kill me with this kind∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: But, now that I have discovered my weakness, be secret; for the least imprudence.—

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: It is a vain fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Call it not vain: my reputation is dearer to me than my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Where can it find so sure a guard? the grave auste∣rity of my life will dumb-found suspicion, and yours may defy detraction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Well, Doctor, 'tis you must answer for my folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I take it all upon myself. Heaven, 'tis true, forbids certain gratifications; but there are ways of reconcile∣ment, and laying the fears of a too scrupulous con∣science.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Every way, I perceive, you are determined to get the better of me; but there's one thing still to be afraid of.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Nothing, nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: My husband, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Alas, poor man! I will answer for him. Between ourselves, Madam, your husband is weak; I can lead him by the nose any where.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: Lady LAMBERT, Doctor CANTWELL, Sir JOHN LAMBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: No, caitiff, I'm to be led no farther.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Ah! woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Is this your sanctity? this your doctrine? these your meditations?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Is then my brother in a conspiracy against me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P:
Your brother! I have been your friend, indeed, to my shame; your dupe; but your spell has lost its hold:
no more canting; it will not serve your turn any lon∣ger.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Now heaven be praised.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: It seems you wanted an excuse to part with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ungrateful wretch! but why do I reproach you? had I not been the weakest of mankind, you never could have proved so great a villain. Get out of my sight; leave my house: of all my follies, which is it tells you, that if you stay much longer, I shall not be tempt∣ed to wrest you out of the hands of the law, and punish you as you deserve?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Well; but first let me ask you, Sir, Who is it you menace? consider your own condition, and where you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: What would the villain drive at? leave me; I forgive you: but once more I tell you, seek some other place; out of my house. This instant begone, and see my shameful face no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Nay then, 'tis my duty to exert myself, and let you know that I am master here. Turn you out, Sir; this house is mine; and now, Sir, at your peril dare to in∣sult me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Oh heaven! 'tis true; whither shall I fly, to hide me from the world?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Whither are you going, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: I know not—but here, it seems, I am a trespasser—the master of this house has warned me hence—and, since the right is now in him, 'tis just I should resign it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P:
You shall not stir. He dares not act with such a∣bandon∣ed
insolence. No, Sir, possession still is yours. If he pretends a right, let him, by open course of law, maintain it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Here! Seyward!

DIV2.STAGE: Sir JOHN, Lady LAMBERT, Old Lady LAM∣BERT, MAW-WORM.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Who is this fellow? what do you want, man?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: My Lady, come up.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: How now!

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: He wants to know who I be.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: The gentleman is a friend of mine, son. I was car∣rying him in my coach to attend a controversy that's to be held this evening, at the Reverend Mr. Scruple's, about an affair of simony, and call'd to take up the Doctor. But what strange tales are these I hear below?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: The Doctor is a villain, Madam; I have detected him; detected him in the horrible design of seducing my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: It's unpossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: What do you say, man?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: I says its unpossible. He has been lock'd up with my wife for hours together, morning, noon, and night, and I never found her the worse for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Ah son! son!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: What is your Ladyship going to say now?

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: The Doctor is not in fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: 'Slife, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: Oh he swears! he swears! years in growing good, we become profligate in a moment. If you swear a∣gain, I wont stay in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: Nor I neither: aren't you asham'd of yourself? have you no commenseration on your soul?—ah! poor wicked sinner! I pity you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: 'Sdeath!

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: If you swear any more, I'll inform against you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Why would you bring this idiot, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: Ay, do despise me, I'm the prouder for it; I likes to be despis'd.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV2.STAGE: Old LADY, Young LADY, Sir JOHN, MAW-WORM▪ CHARLOTTE, afterwards SEYWARD, DARNLEY, Doctor CANTWELL, SERVANTS.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Oh dear papa, I shall faint away; there's murder doing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Who! where! what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: The Doctor, Sir, and Seyward were at high words just now in the garden; and, upon a sudden, there was a pistol fired between them. Oh! I'm afraid poor Sey∣ward is kill'd

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Oh, here he comes himself; he'll tell you more.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: Here, bring in this ruffian; this is villainy beyond example.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: What means this outrage?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I tremble.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: Don't be alarm'd, Madam—there is no mischief done: what was intended, the Doctor here can best inform you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Mr. Darnley, I am ashamed to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: So you ought; but this good man's asham'd of no∣thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Alas! my enemies prevail.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: In short, gentlemen, the affair is circumstantially this—The Doctor called me out into the pavilion in the garden; appear'd in great disorder; told me there was a sudden storm raised, which he was not sufficient∣ly prepared to weather. He said, his dependance was upon me▪ and, at all events, I must e ready to swear, when he called upon me, I had seen him pay Sir John several large sums of money. He talked confusedly a∣bout giving value for an estate, but I boldly refused to perjure myself; and told him, on the contrary, I was satisfied he had fleeced Sir John of several large sums, under pretence of charitable uses, which he secretly converted to his own.—This stung him—and he fast∣ened at my throat. Then, indeed, all temper left me; and, disengaging myself from his hold, with a home∣blow, struck him down. At this, grown desperate, he ran with fury to some pistols that hung above the chim∣ney; but in the instant he reach'd one, I seiz'd upon his wrist; and as we grappled, the pistol firing to the cieling, alarm'd the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: This is a lie, young man. I see the devil standing at your elbow.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: So do I, with a great big pitchfork, pushing him on.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Well, what have you more against me?

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: More, Sir, I hope is needless—but, if Sir John is yet unsatisfied—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: O! I have seen too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: I demand my liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Let him go.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: Old Lady, Young Lady, Sir JOHN, MAW-WORM, CHARLOTTE, SEYWARD, DARNLEY, Doctor CANTWELL, Colonel LAMBERT, TIPSTAFF, and Attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Hold, Sir! not so fast; you can't pass.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Who, Sir, shall dare to stop me?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Within, there!

SP.SPEAKER: TIPSTAFF.
SP.P: Is your name Cantwell, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: What if it be, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: TIPSTAFF.
SP.P: Then Sir, I have my Lord Chief Justice's warrant against you.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Against me?

SP.SPEAKER: TIPSTAFF.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; for a cheat, and impostor.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: What does he say?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: Dear son, what is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Only some actions of the Doctor's, Sir, which I have affidavits in my hand here to prove, from more than one creditable witness, and I think it my duty to make the publick acquainted with: if he can acquit himself of them, so; if not, he must take the conse∣quence.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Well, but stay; let the accusations against me be what they will, by virtue of this conveyance, I am still master here; and, if I am forc'd to leave the house my∣self, I will shut up the doors:—nobody shall remain behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: There! there! indeed he stings me to the heart! for that rash act, reproach and endless shame will haunt me!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: No, Sir!—be comforted.—Even there, too, his wicked hopes must leave him; for know, the fatal deed, which you intended to sign, is here, even yet unseal'd and innocent!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: What means she?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: I mean, Sir, that this deed, by accident falling in∣to this gentleman's hands; his generous concern for our family discovered it to me; and that, in concert, we procured that other to be drawn exactly like it; which, in your impatience to execute, pass'd unsuspect∣ed for the original. Their only difference is, that wherever here you read the Doctor's name, there you'll find my brother's.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor CANTWELL.
SP.P: Come, Sir; lead me where you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Secure your prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Lady LAMBERT.
SP.P: I don't know what to make of all this.

SP.SPEAKER: MAW-WORM.
SP.P: They'll all go to the devil, for what they are doing.—Come away, my Lady, and let us see after the good dear Doctor. Ay, do laugh, you'll go to the devil for all that.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE, the last.
DIV2.STAGE: Lady LAMBERT, Sir JOHN, CHARLOTTE, SEYWARD, DARNLEY, Colonel LAMBERT.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Now, Darnley, I hope I have made atonement for your jealousy.

SP.SPEAKER: DARNLEY.
SP.P: You've banish'd it for ever! this was beyond your∣self surprising.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: Sister—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P: Come, no set speeches; if I deserve your thanks, return them in friendship to your first preserver.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. LAMBERT.
SP.P: The business of my life shall be to merit it.

SP.SPEAKER: SEYWARD.
SP.P: And mine, to speak my sense of obligations.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JOHN LAMBERT.
SP.P: O, my child▪ for my deliverance, I can only re∣ward you here.—For you, my son, whose filial virtue I have injur'd; this honest deed, in every article, shall be ratified.—And, for the sake of that hypocritical villain! I declare, that from henceforward I renounce all pious folks; I will have an utter abhorrence for every thing that bears the appearance—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLOTTE.
SP.P:
Nay, now, my dear Sir, I must take the liberty to tell you, you carry things too far, and go from one extreme to another.—What? because a worthless
wretch has imposed upon you, under the fallacious shew of austere grimace, will you needs have it, every body is like him? confound the good with the bad, and conclude, there are no truly religious in the world.—Leave, my dear Sir, such rash consequences to fools and libertines.—Let us be careful to distinguish between virtue and the appearance of it. Guard, if possible, against doing honour to hypocrisy.—But, at the same time, let us allow there is no character in life, greater or more valuable, than that of the truly de∣vout,—nor any thing more noble, or more beautiful, than the fervour of a sincere piety.
